trans-unit.source: Secure a database in SQL Data Warehouse
trans-unit.target: Secure a database in SQL Data Warehouse

trans-unit.source: This article walks through the basics of securing your Azure SQL Data Warehouse database.
trans-unit.target: This article walks through the basics of securing your Azure SQL Data Warehouse database.

trans-unit.source: In particular, this articles will get you started with resources for limiting access, protecting data, and monitoring activities on a database.
trans-unit.target: In particular, this articles will get you started with resources for limiting access, protecting data, and monitoring activities on a database.

trans-unit.source: Connection security
trans-unit.target: Connection security

trans-unit.source: Connection Security refers to how you restrict and secure connections to your database using firewall rules and connection encryption.
trans-unit.target: Connection Security refers to how you restrict and secure connections to your database using firewall rules and connection encryption.

trans-unit.source: Firewall rules are used by both the server and the database to reject connection attempts from IP addresses that have not been explicitly whitelisted.
trans-unit.target: Firewall rules are used by both the server and the database to reject connection attempts from IP addresses that have not been explicitly whitelisted.

trans-unit.source: To allow your application or client machine's public IP address to attempt connecting to a new database, you must first create a server-level firewall rule using the Azure Management Portal, REST API, or PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: To allow your application or client machine's public IP address to attempt connecting to a new database, you must first create a server-level firewall rule using the Azure Management Portal, REST API, or PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: As a best practice, you should restrict the IP address ranges allowed through your server firewall as much as possible.
trans-unit.target: As a best practice, you should restrict the IP address ranges allowed through your server firewall as much as possible.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure SQL Database firewall][].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure SQL Database firewall][].

trans-unit.source: Authentication
trans-unit.target: Authentication

trans-unit.source: Authentication refers to how you prove your identity when connecting to the database.
trans-unit.target: Authentication refers to how you prove your identity when connecting to the database.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse currently supports SQL Authentication with a username and password.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse currently supports SQL Authentication with a username and password.

trans-unit.source: When you created the logical server for your database, you specified a "server admin" login with a username and password.
trans-unit.target: When you created the logical server for your database, you specified a "server admin" login with a username and password.

trans-unit.source: Using these credentials, you can authenticate to any database on that server as the database owner, or "dbo."
trans-unit.target: Using these credentials, you can authenticate to any database on that server as the database owner, or "dbo."

trans-unit.source: However, as a best practice your organization’s users should use a different account to authenticate -- this way you can limit the permissions granted to the application and reduce the risks of malicious activity in case your application code is vulnerable to a SQL injection attack.
trans-unit.target: However, as a best practice your organization’s users should use a different account to authenticate -- this way you can limit the permissions granted to the application and reduce the risks of malicious activity in case your application code is vulnerable to a SQL injection attack.

trans-unit.source: The recommended approach is to create a contained database user, which allows your app to authenticate directly to a single database with a username and password.
trans-unit.target: The recommended approach is to create a contained database user, which allows your app to authenticate directly to a single database with a username and password.

trans-unit.source: Authorization
trans-unit.target: Authorization

trans-unit.source: Authorization refers to what you can do within an Azure SQL Data Warehouse database, and this is controlled by your user account's role memberships and permissions.
trans-unit.target: Authorization refers to what you can do within an Azure SQL Data Warehouse database, and this is controlled by your user account's role memberships and permissions.

trans-unit.source: As a best practice, you should grant users the least privileges necessary.

trans-unit.source: Auditing
trans-unit.target: Auditing

trans-unit.source: Auditing and tracking database events can help you maintain regulatory compliance and identify suspicious activity.
trans-unit.target: Auditing and tracking database events can help you maintain regulatory compliance and identify suspicious activity.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse Auditing allows you to record events in your database to an audit log in your Azure Storage account.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse Auditing allows you to record events in your database to an audit log in your Azure Storage account.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse Auditing also integrates with Microsoft Power BI to facilitate drill-down reports and analyses.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse Auditing also integrates with Microsoft Power BI to facilitate drill-down reports and analyses.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Get started with SQL Database Auditing][].
